Award.AwardTitle: Symmetry Making and Breaking in the Synthesis and Assembly of Stellated and Bimetallic Nanocrystals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nature demonstrates symmetry in the beauty of a flower, the precision of a honeycomb, and the elaborate patterns of snowflakes. Beyond the appeal of symmetric forms, symmetry can also impart function. For example, orb spiders weave in a spiral pattern to maximize the strength of their webs and bees construct honeycombs with close packed hexagons to maximize honey storage. This correlation between structure and function is also captured in modern nanomaterial design, where changing the symmetry of a nanocrystal or the internal order of a superstructure built from nanocrystals can give novel function. However, the synthesis and assembly of nanomaterials have been limited to simple compositions and structures until recently. In this research, the principal investigator, Sara Skrabalak, is developing new synthetic methods to make metal nanostructures with multiple metals and defined shapes. These nanostructures are also being used as building blocks to form larger structures, where the symmetries of the building blocks direct the shapes of the larger superstructures. The principal investigator and her students also study how the compositions and structures impart functionality. In particular, studies into the new light-matter interactions that arise as a function of symmetry are underway in an effort to achieve multi-functional platforms for chemical sensing applications. Ultimately, this research has broader impacts in the field by forging links between multiple disciplines, including nano/inorganic/solid-state chemistry, condensed matter physics, surface science, and material science. This project also incorporates outreach and educational efforts that introduce nanoscale concepts to non-scientists. The project also involves undergraduates in research activities in ways that emphasize their connection to the surrounding community.

The Skrabalak group at Indiana University is developing seed-mediated co-reduction as a new synthetic strategy to multimetallic nanostructures, where multiple metals are simultaneously deposited onto shape-controlled nanocrystals. The symmetry of the nanocrystal seeds is transferred to the final nanostructures. This research includes studying how lattice mismatch and deposition kinetics contribute to bimetallic distribution. This work is coupled with a study of how symmetry can be reduced along specific crystallographic directions during seed-mediated co-reduction in order to achieve new stellated nanocrystal symmetries and in turn functional diversification. Finally, the Skrabalak group is using the stellated metal nanocrystals to assemble close-packed and low-density lattices to expand crystallization capabilities to new structural classes. They also characterize the collective optical properties that emerge. These three aims are coupled with outreach and educational efforts in which undergraduate researchers are Science Ambassadors to their former high schools, introducing nanoscale concepts to students and serving as role models to those interested in science, technology, engineering and mathematics fields. Advancement in the research expands the classes of nanocrystals and superstructures possible and identifies the roles of seed and building block symmetry in the synthesis and assembly of metal nanocrystals for broader impact in the science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Synthetic methods that couple compositional complexity with structural precision are a critical need. NSF Award 1602476 ?Symmetry Making and Breaking in the Synthesis and Assembly of Stellated and Bimetallic Nanocrystals? provided resources to advance seed-mediated methods as a route to achieve compositionally complex nanomaterials with structural precision. Several concepts were demonstrated. First, regioselective deposition on seeds was demonstrated at the extreme of low supersaturation and aided through the use of capping agents. This demonstration provides insight into how symmetry breaking can be achieved controllably in seeded methods. Second, planar defects in seeds were found to direct deposition, where branches would emerge from the faces of seeds rather than propagate the defects. This outcome is likely the result of exchanging strain energy for surface energy and provides new insight into branched nanocrystal synthesis beyond kinetically controlled pathways. Third, chemoselective galvanic replacement was demonstrated with bimetallic dimers, illustrating a potentially general route toward nanostructures with multiple multimetallic domains. Each of these demonstrations was made possible because seeds, much like a stick is used to nucleate sugar when making rock candy, serve as preferential sites for the deposition of additional material.

This award also enabled the study of how bimetallic composition and structure influence the properties of plasmonic materials. In particular, stellated bimetallic nanostructures were developed as a new class of plasmonic colloids in which the interplay between composition and overall architecture can provide tunable optical properties and new multi-functionality. In fact, these nanocrystals display the highest ensemble sensitivity to changes in refractive index (environment) for colloids with localized surface plasmon resonances positioned in the visible region. They also display high thermal and photothermal stability compared to all-gold nanostructures.

This project led to 13 peer-reviewed publications in top-tier journals at grant closure. Moreover, 1 post-doctoral scholar, 8 graduate students, and 10 undergraduates were trained fully or in-part through this project, including nearly ~50% women. PhD students have achieved top industrial positions, with nearly all Indiana University undergraduate researchers involved in this project completing or pursuing advanced degrees. Also, an interactive touchscreen activity based on metal nanoparticles and art was developed in collaboration with Indiana University?s Advanced Visualization Laboratory and educational staff at Wonderlab, a science museum for children based in Bloomington, Indiana.

Ultimately, this research provided design criteria for the synthesis of nanocrystals with high symmetry and complex compositions through seeded methods as well as strategies for symmetry breaking. The new nanostructures achieved are providing new opportunities in plasmonics. This research also forged links between scientific disciplines that include nanoscience, inorganic and solid-state chemistry, condensed matter physics, surface science, and material science by providing novel nanostructure platforms to study the impact of composition and structure on properties.


Last Modified: 09/05/2019
Modified by: Sara Skrabalak
